results.title: Children of fire
results.creator_credit: Mai Masri, George Khleifi, Fatima Masri, BBC-TV and M T C
results.brief_description: Nablus, situated in the Israeli Occupied West Bank and home to 120,000 exiled Palestinians is also the home of filmmaker Mai Masri. It is 9 September 1989 and fourteen years since Mai has been in Nablus when she returns to her hometown to document Palestinian life since the beginning of the Intifada. Mai very quickly finds out that Nablus is not the peaceful town where she grew up - it is instead a place of violence, death, fear and tension, where young children have been robbed of their innocence and often their lives. The Palestinians in Nablus are constantly under survellience the Israeli Army which only serves to heighten the frustration and determination of the younger generation to fight for their freedom and confront the occupiers head-on, albeit with weapons of stones. Children as young as five are aware of their situation as exiles and from the ages of six and seven, many will become street-fighters, their games often replicating real life. Through these children’s personal stories and the violent images in their childish paintings, as well as some rather disturbing film footage of the Israeli soldiers in action, Mai Masri presents an uncompromising and courageous portrayal of Nablus and the children of the Intifada. (Awards: Cairo Television Festival 1995; Feminin Pluriel Festival) In English and Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: Children of Federation
results.brief_description: This is a look at Australia’s history since Federation in 1901 through the eyes of 6 Gallipoli veterans. As a group of children who came through Federation, they describe what is has been like to have lived in a country that has gone from horse-drawn carriages to the space age. They talk about fashion, music, youth, politics and many other things. They also discuss Australia’s involvement in wars and how they felt, as veterans of Gallipoli, sending their children to World War 2.

results.title: Children of Dune
results.creator_credit: Greg Yaitanes, David Kappes, New Amsterdam Entertainment and Sci Fi Pictures
results.brief_description: Impressive adaptation of two Frank Herbert novels, “Dune Messiah” and “Children of Dune” this made for television mini-series continues the epic science-fiction saga that is “Dune”. On the desert planet of Dune, the ancient prophecy has been fulfilled - the rule of the legendary Maud’dib has triggered a miraculous transformation of the arid wastelands, and where there was once only desert, water now flows. But as always the great Houses of the Empire are awash with political intrigue and betrayal, ambition, desire and destiny. Enhanced by extensive use of CGI, this series ably captures the eerie otherworldliness of Herbert’s desert setting whilst also establishing the requisite mordant tone. Cast includes Alec Newman, Julie Cox, Steven Berkoff and Susan Sarandon.

results.title: Children of China
results.brief_description: In this film, the home and community customs, the school training, and the family relationships which concern children in a remote and primitive Chinese village before World War 2, are studied.

results.title: Children of change
results.creator_credit: Henwar Rodakiewicz, Irving Jacoby and Mental Health Film Board
results.brief_description: This film shows the Day Care Centres as developed in Philadelphia where the children of working mothers are looked after. A trained social worker interviews parents and co-ordinates the activities of the centre with those of the home. Provision is made for older children after school hours. Some young children are placed with selected private families. Discusses reasons why women go out to work.

results.title: Children of Brunei
results.creator_credit: Yvonne MacKay, Dave Gibson, Radio Television Brunei and Gibson Film Productions
results.brief_description: The film shows the life of two children in Brunei at school, reading the Koran, working at the markets, fishing and attending a wedding procession, emphasising the Muslim observance of religious ceremonies. Brunei is one of the last remaining monarchies in the world. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Children of Bangkok
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, Thanan Soongnarata, John Morris and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian Neighbours: Thailand”.
The film follows three Bangkok boys, from different economic classes through a typical day. One boy is the son of an Army colonel in the upper middle class, the second, the son of a middle-class shopkeeper and the third, the son of a lower class migrant farm worker. The film shows a cross section of life in Bangkok.

results.title: Children of alcohol
results.creator_credit: Gil Cardinal, Anne Wheeler, Tom Radford and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This documentary focuses on children of alcoholics. In the relaxed environment of a mountain campsite, a group of young people discuss their anger and frustration, and talk about their struggle to cope with the problems created by their parents’ drinking. By sharing their experiences, they open a door for others like them. Aimed primarily at an audience of elementary school children and older, Children of Alcohol will provide an excellent vehicle for generating discussion about alcohol abuse and the family.

results.title: Children of a lesser god
results.creator_credit: Randa Haines, Patrick Palmer, Burt Sugarman and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on Mark Medoff’s Tony Award-winning (1980) play. It is a touching and poignant love story between a deaf woman and a hearing man. William Hurt gives a sensitive performance as James a likeable schoolmaster, whose job is to teach hearing impaired people to speak. Sarah (Marlee Matlin - who is hearing impaired in real life) is a young beautiful girl who leaves school with a chip on her shoulder and with the knowledge that sex needs no conversation. The touching portrayal of their attraction makes it impossible not to share the experience. Matlin won the 1987 Academy Award for Best Actress with nominations for Best Picture, Best Actor, Best Supporting Actress and Best Adapted Screenplay.
